awd_titl_txt: RoL: FELS: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Genomics of exceptions to scaling of longevity to body size
awd_abstract_narration:
In mammals, as body size increases so does maximum lifespan, but bats represent an exception to this rule. This project will use a detailed genomic analysis to examine how bats live significantly longer than expected. Bat species studied to date can live up to six times longer than expected based on their body mass. Achieving unusually long life requires enhanced cell and tissue upkeep, maintaining immune function, and avoiding mutations that cause cancer and other age-related diseases. Hence, their exceptionally long lives require that bats evolve mechanisms to enable these features. To discover the genetic basis of healthy old age, this project focuses on pairs of closely related bat species that sharply differ in their longevity. Detailed genome comparisons between closely related species with different life spans will test different theories of aging. Although genome sequences are available for many mammals, including some bats, in most cases these are too incomplete to allow detailed comparisons. For this reason, the project also seeks to combine modern DNA sequencing techniques to produce genome sequences at greater resolution and lower cost than hitherto possible. The resulting methods can be applied across many other mammals, and vertebrates more generally. The project will also support the production of new teaching materials on evolutionary biology for secondary school students and research experiences for teachers, as well as the development of new research and analytical approaches for use by the scientific community.

The scaling of longevity by body size relates the biology of populations to the molecular mechanisms of cells and tissues making up individuals, but the nature of the connections is debated. Some theories suggest that aging is the result of genetic trade-offs imposed by the diminishing chances of reproduction of older individuals (Evolutionary Theory), while others propose that aging results from molecular and cellular damage as organisms move through life (Damage Theory). This project will test these broad theories through comparative analyses of high-quality genome sequences. Besides generating at least five high quality mammalian genomes to complement existing or ongoing ones, the project will relate longevity phenotypes to genotypes across the genome sequence including genes, pseudogenes, transcription factors, and variation in the number of copies of certain genes. Coupled with analyses of genomic methylation and RNA transcripts, the project will identify candidate regions underlying divergent longevities, enabling future functional analyses at the scale of tissues, cells, and molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: In mammals, as body size increases so does maximum lifespan. Some theories suggest that senescence is the result of genetic trade-offs imposed by the decreasing reproductive value of older individuals (Evolutionary Theory), while others propose that aging results from molecular and cell damage as organisms move through life (Damage Theory). Many bats have escaped this Rule of Life (RoL), with much greater longevity than would be expected by body size. Bats are therefore an excellent clade to test hypotheses and predictions related to theories aging. Unfortunately, studies of bats have not strategically sampled differing longevities and life histories, and lacked the high-quality assemblies needed to address these theories.
This project addressed these limitations by testing hypotheses related to the major theories of aging. We generated reference-quality genomes from selected pairs of bats that either defy or adhere to this RoL. Specifically, the species were chosen because of their contrasting patterns of exceptionally high or low longevity quotients, paired with their distinct life history strategies. To reduce potential confounding factors related to evolutionary divergence, pairs selected were at least members of the same family, and when possible, were members of the same genus. The resulting sampling regime has provided the first example of a comparative data set specifically designed to test hypotheses related to the Evolutionary and Damage Theories of aging.
The project consisted of two major objectives:
1) Generate very high-quality genomes for a sample of bats with varying life histories and longevities. We will set new standards for cost-effective comparative genome sequencing in non-model mammals, and
2) Analyze the resulting comparative data at multiple levels of organization, from mutations within orthologous genes, to varying rates of evolution for individual genes, as well as gains and losses
of genes across pathways.
Objective 1 was completely successful. During the project, we generated four new genome assemblies, all published or to-be-published in high-impact journals. This includes Hypsignathus monstrosus (the hammerhead bat), Eptesicus fuscus (the large brown bat), Phyllostomus hastatus (the greater spear-nosed bat), and Antrozous pallidus (the pallid bat). Our most recent accepted publication (in Science) pioneers comparative methods relating traits to genomes. We also participated in a larger project that directed the assembly of six equally high-quality assemblies, published in Nature. Additional assemblies are underway and will be incorporated into ongoing downstream analyses associated with the project and its objectives.
Objective 2 is partially complete and still underway. Initial comparative genomics utilizing the genome assemblies resulted in one major publication in Molecular Ecology. In that publication, we describe gene gains and losses, rates of molecular evolution, with a focus on genes associated with immunity and metabolism, both important factors in determining longevity.  Specifically, we identified lineage specific expansions of the APOBEC3 and MHC-I gene families, loss of the proinflammatory PYHIN gene family, losses of genes involved in regulation of inflammasome pathways, and parallel gene expansions associated with the evolution of plant feeding.
Broader Impacts: The COVID-19 pandemic was a hindrance to some objectives associated with this project but we were still able to implement most activities. With the closing of schools, we shifted our efforts in educating high school teachers to undergraduates in our respective courses and laboratories. Dr. Ray incorporated four undergraduate students in efforts to examine genome structure and gene family evolution in bats in comparison to other mammals. In addition, the genome assemblies generated by this project were actively used as part of two courses, Genomes and Society and Genomes and Genome Evolution. Dr. Davalos incorporated four graduate students into the project, all of whom were mentored in genomics techniques. Two of the students designed and conducted internships, one at the New York Hall of Science and one at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories, to make genomics tools accessible to all. The results of those internships directly link this project to the general public and provide scalable educational tools.
Finally, the award was used to support multiple additional publications and presentations, including Thus far these awards have supported work associated with five publications [1, 2] including two in Nature [3, 4] and one in Molecular Ecology [5]. Two additional publications associated with the project are under review at high-impact journals [6-8], and one has been accepted. Persons associated with the work and analyses delivered eight seminars or lectures at a variety of local and international venues.

1.    Yohe, L.R., et al., G3 Genes|Genomes|Genetics, 2021. 11(10): p. jkab260.
2.    Korstian, J.M., et al., Genes, 2022. 13(3).
3.    Jebb, D., et al., Nature, 2020. 583(7817): p. 578-584.
4.    Genereux, D.P., et al., Nature, 2020. 587(7833): p. 240-245.
5.    Moreno Santillan, D.D., et al., Mol Ecol, 2021. 30(23): p. 6449-6467.
6.    Zoonomia, C., Science, Submitted.
7.    Paulat, N.S., et al., Science, Submitted.
8.    Osmanski, A.B., et al., Insights into mammalian TE diversity via the curation of 200+ mammalian genome assemblies. Science, Submitted.
